OFFICE OF
DE CORDOVA & SON,
TEXAS
LAND, TAX & GENERAL AGENCY ESTABLISHED 1848.
FINANCIAL AGENTS,
INVESTMENTS MADE IN
VENDORS LIEN NOTES OR
SECURED BY TRUST DEED
WITH POWER OF SALE.
TO NETT 10% INTEREST.
PARTICULAR ATTENTION GIVEN TO THE SALE OF
LANDS AND PROCEEDS PROMPTLY REMITTED.
TAXES PAID ON LANDS IN EVERY COUNTY IN THE STATE,
LANDS EXAMINED, DIVIDED AND PERPARED FOR SALE IN
SMALL TRACTS TO SUIT THE TIMES.
TITLES EXAMINED, PERFECTED AND RECORDED IN THE
PROPER COUNTIES.
Austin Nov 10th 1887

Rev Dr. S. Morais
No 548 North Fifth Str
Philadelphia, Pa.
My dear Sir

I thank you for your note of the 6th.
I have a distinct recollection of it being my
understanding when a boy, that the father of the
"boys & girls" was Hazan of the Congregation, yet
I may be mistaken. How was Eleaser designated
when called to the Toro?

I was one of the scholars who studied under the
Rev. J. Keys and was going to school to him at the
time of his death. I shall think that Eleazor,
and even the youngest of the lot was at least
40 years of age at the time of the death of Mr. Keys.
I send you by mail the remains of an old pamphlet
published in Philadelphia 65 years since, wether the
Rabbi Cohen ever came to Philadelphia or not
I cannot say, but it shows that Philadelphia Jews
even that long time ago took an interest in our holy
faith sufficient to leave a book of introduction for
the young published.

Many old Citizens of Philadelphia must recollect
the printer Wm Fry. For many years he published
in connection with Robert Walsh, Consul U. S. at
Paris under President Tyler, a Newspaper, called the
"National Gazette". His father was doorkeeper
of the Continental Congress and died from joy
when the news of the defeat of the Cornwallis was
received by that august body.

My own recollection of the Congregation Mickve
Israel go back to 1824 or 1825. I cannot satisfactorily
locate which--but on "Yom Kippur" for the first
time I recollect that my beloved mother took me
with her to hear the prayers.

The Congregation had no synagogue at that
period. I think the Cherry Str edifice was
then building. The service was held at the residence
of my relative A. C. Peixotto on, 5th Str
opposite Gowell in the third story and the Tora
was kept in the drawer of a Mahogany Bureau.
The Reader was the Reverend Benoadou
he came from Barbary and read through
his nose, methinks I hear him now.-for once
heard it was never to be forgotten.

I recollect distinctly the night of the consecration
of the Cherry Str sinagogue, and I had until

lately the published pamphlet of the whole
proceedings, but it was disappeared much to my
regret

Of the Rev Mr. Keys, as one of his scholars
I have a most vivid recollection. He was a good
man--considerably hen pecked--had a fine voice
and it seemed to me an unmoderate fancy for [?]
he was always drinking it.

In his Canonicals--with knee breeches--
silk stockings and low quartered shoes, he looked
every inch the "Parson".

I think you will find that you had a Hazan
of the name of Samuel Nunes Carvalho. I
recollect his widow--she survived her husband
in very straightened circumstances a number
of years, dying about 1832.

Lightly may the sod even rest on the remains
of my dear old schoolmaster the Rev. Isaac
Leeser--he was the first Hazan in America,
that delivered lectures in English, but he was
orthodox to the last days of his life and to me
he always appeared as a conscientious religious
man. I recollect the stormy times in the
in the Congregation before he was selected
as the successor to Rev. Mr. Keys. My father
was chairman of the committee of correspondence
who invited Leeser to visit Philadelphia, a Mr
Goldsmith was another member and a Mr
Cohen--which one of numerous Cohens, I
have forgotten.

Salaries in those days were very small--Leeser
was induced to come under the offer of $1000 pr
annum, but his first engagement the Congregation
only gave him $800, equal however to $1500
in the present time.

I could write much more of this sort but
I do not see what right I have to take up your
time, with my garrulity.

12 months since I had a stroke of Paralysis
and I am much impeded in use of my right
arm--at times suffer much--my clerk copies
this letter.

With the found hope that you may long be
spared to preside over Mickve Israel
Yours very truly
P De Cordova

Can you give me the
States of the organisation
of Congregation in N. Y.
Montreal & Phila
